title: Thursday, 22nd March, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am

J L Morning

Here we go again, I guess. Good morning welcometomarketsliveftalphaville'sdailythingwiththetyping.

J L Space bar stuck ;-)
Manxish Morning online people
Pseudonym whoneedsspacesandpunctuationanyway
Blank canvas morning
BE11:05am

I was just trying to find an article I wrote about a million years ago about the history of the FTSE 100 on the occasions that it hit 7k, the gist being that you should probably sell whenever it does.

11:05 am

Peace and Love Bore Da

Miss Piggy haha 6k
Cloudy The FTSE 100 needs a script issue.

Blame the Fed, I guess? Or sterling? Or ..... uh, retail?

Miss Piggy Sell, sell, sell
BE11:08am

15 month low now for the FTSE, if you care about your size and scopes. Let's put that as a picture why not.

BE11:09am

Boom.

So, US team did their macro live thing overnight for the Fed.

Miss Piggy This is one of the biggest clichés in markets: “Stocks take an escalator up, and an elevator down”.
BE11:10am

We'll therefore keep the grey here to a minimum.

Miss Piggy @BE: there wasn''t any grey from US Macro live.
Mouselet 'stocks grow along a boringly uniform exponential with pimples^Wbloody great abscesses in 2000 and 2007'
BBOC ISAT on the cusp of trading at the lowest levels since 2008
Soundbuy @BornCynic - more time on their hands, less time spent trawling the bars and hotels of Mayfair............
11:10 am
BE11:11am

The upshot is 25bps as expected, plus a steeper
trajectory of rate hikes and a terminal funds rate edged higher.

Mouselet The interesting question is whether Elon Musk and Masayoshi Son will get their ISAT-obsoleting constellations launched before they run out of money
BE11:11am

Powell sounding pretty confident in the presser afterwards.

Miss Piggy Only one more dot (on the dot plot) to turn hawkish and then the median is for 4 rate hikes this year.
BE11:11am

Here's Roubini.

Miss Piggy I thought Powell was fidgety. Poor poker player I should imagine.
11:11 am
BE11:12am

The most interesting outcome of the meeting was the Summary of Economic Projections (SEP). The median estimate for the end-2018 fed funds rate remained at 2.1%, while the “dots” for 2019, 2020 and for the longer run were all raised. Note, however, the median estimate for 2018 would have risen to 2.4%, implying four rate hikes in 2018, if just one more “dot” had shifted upward. Assuming hawkish Marvin Goodfriend is confirmed to the Board of Governors, the median estimate for 2018 is likely to shift to four hikes this year.

Mouselet What's the goodwill-doesn't-exist valuation of Microfocus, I wonder?
BE11:12am

The median “dot” for 2020, at 3.4%, is 50 bps higher than the longer run estimate of the fund rate, up from 30 bps in the December SEP. Though Powell did not say so outright, his comments suggest that newly expansionary fiscal policy may account for some of the rise in the funds rate path and for the increased gap between the 2020 and long-run median “dots”.

Mouselet I have decided to move slightly out of cash and into shiny computers and durable musical instruments
BornCynic GSK trying to buy a bit of Pfizer. They've got that wrong - best way to make money out of Pfizer is to sell them something - they always, well used to, overpay.
BE11:14am

... actually, let's not get bogged down in bloody dots. There's enough of that elsewhere.

11:13 am
undefined
MnM Am moving out of eqt and cash and into a new kitchen, as London property sags......

BE11:14am

So ........... Here's a bad day!

GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,282, down 14.6 (-1.13%), High: 1,288, Low: 1,277, Volume: 2.73m
Mouselet I hope the kitchen makes you happy

Tom Dalgleish I'm thinking of moving into used caravans
MnM You can be right or you can be happy!
BE11:15am

An upgrade, say, queued up to launch into the ether at 4am.

Mouselet On the whole I think (with one or two notable exceptions) the people on this side are against grinding one's boots into the faces of the poor, which used caravans are quite prone to being
Pseudonym So when I need access to the internet I should buy a bassoon rather than a computer?
BE11:16am

You've got some elegant paragraphs set up on the cover page like .....

11:16 am
BE11:16am

CEO Emma Walmsley has been increasingly vocal about capital allocation and the prioritization of investment in the pharma pipeline. From her comments at the 2017 results, we understand that a large consumer deal is now less likely than it was a few months ago , which diminishes pressure on cash flow and the risk of a dividend cut. Additionally, recent comments from Novartis suggest that the exercise of the JV put option might not happen in the immediate future, which lessens pressure on the balance sheet.

Tom Dalgleish Just see a used musical instrument salesman
Mouselet Buy a bassoon and a computer now, and when you sell the bassoon after thirty years of happy and lung-strengthening bassooning you can buy a whole shed of computers
BE11:17am

And in the exec summary like .....

BE11:17am

Our takeaway from these comments is that an acquisition of the Pfizer business now seems less likely than it was a few months ago. We see this change in stance as a positive as an acquisition of this size would bring execution risk and a likely decrease of the dividend from the current 80p/year, which is sensitive for a large part of
the investor base.

Pseudonym So the bassoon is a hedge against the depreciation of the computer?
Miss Piggy UK retail sales MoM +0.8 (vs +0.4 forecast)
Mouselet Why is it an issue that an analyst comes to a conclusion which the board of the company happen not to agree with?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And then, about 9pm, long after you've signed off everything with compliance and gone home, this story drops.

BE11:18am

https://www.ft.com...-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4

Mouselet I think computers may have stopped depreciating all that much
Waterloo See support for any Russia action is at best muted/disinterested (noted Trump tweet about playing nice with Russia).
BE11:18am

GlaxoSmithKline is in pole position to win the race to acquire the consumer healthcare business of US pharmaceuticals giant Pfizer after it beat a rival bid from Reckitt Benckiser.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

I mean, fine, stuff like that happens.

Soundbuy £30k for a Schreiber WS5051 Contra Bassoon..............!!!
Mouselet Ah, so that's why RB has gone up. It seemed unlikely that demand for condoms and dettol would change by 6% overnight
Swedish Chef @mouse most ROTR would sympathize with a redundant printer in Gateshead on Brexitland while appreciating the comedy value of #bluepassportgate
Mouselet Contrabassoons are very much more expensive than the normal ones
BE11:19am

Course, it's going to be a bit awkward if you're an analyst at the broker that's advising Pfizer on the Consumer Healthcare auction.

Miss Piggy Compare Russia GDP per capita with oil price and you realise that any Russian leader needs to find excuses for downtrends in exogenous factors.
BE11:19am

Which Morgan Stanley is.

Mouselet swedish chef: I think I agree ... I am a little surprised De La Rue didn't try harder to win the contract
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Morgan Stanley is acting as financial advisor to Pfizer, Inc. (“Pfizer”) in connection with its review of strategic alternatives for its Consumer Healthcare business, as announced on October 10, 2017

BE11:20am

Chinese walls in action, I guess.

Mouselet since layoffs are expensive. But presumably there are 193 other countries that want passports and currency printed.
BE11:20am

So congratulations to MOST for their excellent standards of compliance.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

To his credit, MOST's Vincent Meunier just rolls with it this morning.

Mouselet (normal bassoons are only hand-made at the highest levels, whilst the demand for contrabassoons is sufficiently low that they're all hand-made items; also they use large amounts of fancy wood)
Pharma @Swedish, with the caveat that the EU was the reason the contract had to be offered abroad, so the Gatehead printer would not be minded to change his vote anytime soon.
Mouselet making perfect smooth half-torus tubes out of wood is quite a job
BE11:21am

At the rumoured price of $18bn, and assuming 20% cost synergies, we estimate that the deal would be mid-single digit EPS accretive from year 3, with ROCE of 7% in year 3 (above GSK's WACC from year 4). We calculate GSK's net debt/EBITDA would reach 2.8x in 2019 and not be back below 2x before 2023. As well, we calculate that the exercise of the Novartis put option in 2018 on top of PFE CHC would bring GSK's net debt / EBITDA to 3.6x in 2019 and still at 2.7x in 2023. As we said in our note published today on GSK, a key takeout from FY17 results is the CEO comment that GSK "will not do anything that cuts across that prioritization", adding that GSK is satisfied with its current consumer business as it is, suggesting that a deal was less likely. We are not aware of any official comment from GSK.

BE11:22am

As for Reckitt, the mvoe tells its own story.

11:21 am
Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 5,919, up 293 (+5.21%), High: 6,067, Low: 5,861, Volume: 1.70m
BornCynic You would think with their huge salaries that the board of Pfizer would be able to pick up a phone and ring round other boards saying "want to buy this" rather than paying MOST a small fortune to do it? Or am I being simplistic?

BE11:23am

Over-pay risk off the table, along with integration risk and likelihood of a dirty great rights issue.

Mouselet Is it Warren Buffet who is only interested in requests-to-be-acquired coming directly from the CEO?
BE11:23am

Here's Merrill.

Miss Piggy I'm gonna write a Chrome extension to filter comments about bassoons.
Mouselet Sorry
Tom Dalgleish A modest hurdle to your musicoinvestment ambitions
Mouselet (though I imagine it will be a useful exercise)
11:23 am
BE11:23am

The risks associated with the acquisition of PFE CH included (1) a hotly contested auction process resulting in an hefty multiple paid by RB; a price range of $15-20bn was cited in a recent Bloomberg article (5 Feb 2018) for the PFE CH unit equating to an EV/EBITDA range of 20-26x; (2) RB’s Net Debt/ EBITDA increasing to a range of 4.9x - 5.8x, potentially forcing the company to do a rights issue at a relatively depressed share price (RB’s shares down -17% year to date vs. EU HPC sector down -8%); (3) integration of such a large asset could have added complexity and further disruptions to RB’s operations that are already undergoing a major transformation with the creation of two separate business units (RB Health and RB HyHo); (4) slight uncertainty around PFE CH’s organic sales growth profile in a context of PFE’s Nexium brand facing, since the end of September, generic/ private label competition; and (5) the deal might have been viewed by some as an attempt by RB to hide the issues faced by its core business.

Pseudonym @Mouselet Ditch the baboon and use a synth it's cheaper.
BE11:24am

And Redburn, somewhat more succinctly.

BE11:24am

Following its sharp YTD underperformance, Reckitt’s shares trade on a 2018F P/E of 17.0x, which is almost the lower under our coverage. With many perceived risks associated with acquisition of the Pfizer business no longer present, the rehabilitation of Reckitt can begin here. Buy.

Ted Baker reported FY18 PBT of £73.5mn, +11.7% yoy (Bloomberg consensus £74.2mn, GSe £74mn), with cFX revenues of +9.6% (GSe +8.7%). Geographically, UK and Europe retail sales rose +6.4% during the year (GSe +9.4%), with North America +12.4% (GSe +6.6%) and MEAAA +17.3% (GSe +11%). Gross margins were flat at 61% (consensus 60.1%, GSe 60%), with retail margin improving (+90bps to 67%) due to higher full price sell through and better product mix, offset partially by wholesale margins being weighed on mix shift towards lower margin territorial license partner sales (-180bps to 43.3%). EBIT margins -70bps to 11.9% (consensus 13%, GSe 13%)

11:35 am
BE11:35am

FY19E guidance:
- Wholesale revenue growth “high single digits” cFX (GSe c.+9%) - Capex £30mn (GSe £30mn)

What does it all mean? Other things equal, we expect FY19E PBT Bloomberg consensus of £83.5mn to reduce by c2% (EPS £1.39, +8.8%) given slight miss to consensus earnings and weak recent trading

There are relatively few retailers delivering 10%
profit growth; Ted remains one of the sector’s few global structural growth stocks. If we were being churlish, we could point to stronger earnings growth at Superdry and Joules, both of which offer a higher level of self-help growth at this juncture, with Superdry arguably likely to benefit more from an extended winter than its peers. Nonetheless, trading on c21x, Ted continues to offer an attractive and sustainable global growth opportunity and represents a core sector holding.

.... a cautious view on Ted means c10% profit growth rather than 12-13%. We trim our FY2019 PBT forecast by £3m to £81m, although earnings remain unchanged thanks to the lower US tax rates.

Facebook down 2% pre-market. It's the law now that we note this each day.

Stifel .....

doeswalk i remember someone telling me the back around 2012 that the facebook API let you access almost anything
BE11:43am

We are lowering our 12-month target price on Facebook shares to $168 from $195, based on a
100 basis point increase to the discount rate in our discounted cash flow analysis. Facebook’s
current plight reminds us of eBay in 2004 – an unstructured content business built on trust that
lost that trust prior to implementing policies to add structure and process. Just like PayPal was
going to save eBay, Instagram may save Facebook…eventually. To further the comparison,
we can even borrow eBay’s The Power of Three tagline (eBay/PayPal/Skype and Facebook/
Instagram/WhatsApp)! That said, Facebook’s business is much bigger than eBay's was, and the
damage currently being done is potentially more significant – user well-being, possible external
influence on elections, and “data things.”

doeswalk so i suspect others did
11:44 am
BE11:44am

It's actually a pretty good note. Though not in the sense of giving investment advice.

VV75 Any comment on the Interserve financing deal?
BE11:44am

Why did this happen? A business needs to make money. A platform built on community,
traffic aggregation, and time-spent monetizes via advertising. To maximize advertising revenue,
Facebook benefits from building product to drive engagement and time spent on its platform.
Until recently, it seemed key operating metrics included users, engagement (DAU/MAU), and
time spent. Now Mr. Zuckerberg seems to more want the time on the platform to be well-spent.
Why? Was it proactive or reactive? We don’t know. How does Facebook truly fix important issues
on the platform, as Mr. Zuckerberg set out to do at the outset of 2018? Facebook likely cleans
up the product, which in turn drives down usage and monetization. If Facebook does the right
thing, it likely negatively impacts the advertising business in the short-to-intermediate term. Will
Facebook do the right thing? We don’t know. If Facebook does the wrong thing, it could run into
more trouble in the future. Will Facebook do the wrong thing? We don’t know.

BBOC You can now no longer (but only just) buy the entirety of JPM + GS with facebook market cap :(
BE11:45am

Neil Campling, now of Mirabaud, also reliably good.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We also think brands will now question their digital marketing strategies and dumb dollar commitments to the platform. What we mean by that is that we have, after discussions with some brands, found no CPG company that can accurately quantify the ROI of the social digital advertising spend. But isn't this essential as the differentiator between social media spend rather than, say, TV advertising? Facebook increased advertising pricing by 43% in Q4 last year. Yes, 43%. They won't be able to do that again in a hurry.

Miss Piggy GBPUSD up 1% today
BE11:46am

Much has already been written and we don't want to retread old ground. But wall street estimates so far are unmoved, yet the threat to both top line and operating leverage has to be considered real. The result is that Facebook optically looks "cheap" and revisions appear stable. We have seen this proverbial movie play out countless times in tech as earnings momentum fades, multiple compression hits and incremental buyers disappear

11:52 am

BE11:53am

We have updated our forecasts to reflect the higher
interest cost (£56m in FY18E, £70m thereafter), increased cost of bonding and assume that all warrants
are exercised, reducing our FY18E/FY19E earnings forecasts by 55%/60%. We acknowledge that these forecasts contain a high degree of uncertainty and may well change again materially post-strategy update. Whilst the picture remains unclear and any operational recovery is unlikely to be linear, we upgrade to Buy with a 130p target price, valuing the group on 6.5x FY18E EBITDA, before deducting net debt and the pension deficit and dividing by 182m shares, which assumes all warrants are exercised. The agreement with lenders reduces near-term uncertainty on financing, and implies no further material downside from EfW or the wider contract review, two key areas of concern. It also suggests the lenders will allow the group time in implementing a solution to structurally reduce its net debt.
